div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

SATURDAY, MAY 25, 1907.

div.head: THE LIBERAL GOVERNMENT.
div.p: The telegrams from London on the rejection of Mr. Birrell's Bill by the Dublin Convention clearly show from the chagrin of the Ministerial Press that, the blow is the bitterest that the Government has yet sustained. As the "Spectator remarked recently, no impartial observer of current politics can review the position of the Government witho it coming to the conclusion that it is one of difficulty, if not, indeed, of danger. It is true that they still command immense majorities in the House of Commons, and that whenever the full voting force of the party is put in motion they can carry their measures or their resolutions by overwhelming numbers. This, however, must not blind us to the fact that Governments, apparently quite as strong in outward strength, have fallen from internal dissensions, or from a kind of feverish confusion which has brought them to an end no one exactly knows how or why.

Lord Rosebery the other day warned the Government that they were in danger of offending simultaneously both of the camps into which their supporters are divided. They were not going far enough with the extremists to gain their loyal support, and yet going far enough with them to alienate the moderate section of the Liberal Party. Every day this fact is being brought more clearly into prominence. For example, the policy adopted in regard to old-age pensions has filled moderate Liberals with alarm, while at the same time it is scouted as a mockery and delusion by the Labour Party. Nor can we wonder that this is so. We see old age pension proposals defended, not on their merits, but on the ground that it would not he safe to allow the Tariff Reformers to Associate the cause of old-age pensions with Protection. A method of treating great social and political questions so fundamentally dishonest cannot but bring disaster to those who adopt it. Look, again, at the attitude of the Government towards land legislation. Bills like the Scotch Land Bill now before the House are spreading alarm among moderate Liberals throughout the country, not merely because they are predatory, hut even more because they are thoroughly unpractical. Yet these proposals, though they alienate moderate support, by no means win the whole-hearted approval of the Socialist and Labour extremists. In the same way, we have little doubt that when the Government plan for dealing with the House of Lords is produced, it will be found to alarm moderate opinion profoundly, without satisfying those who wish to see the House of Commons armed with the unchecked and uncontrolled powers wielded by the Convention in the French Revolution,—a body, that is, whose mere resolutions are at once clothed with the might and majesty of the law.

div.head: Fatality at Mex.
div.p: Yesterday a native was killed by a fall of earth while working in a quarry at Mex.

div.head: H. M. S. Minerva.
div.p: H. M. S. "Minerva" left Port Said at 6 p.m. on Thursday. She is expected to be away for about ten days.

div.head: Yachts at Alexandria.
div.p: The French yacht "Isle de France and the Spanish yacht "Espana" arrived at Alexandria harbour this morning.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin shows three deaths at Assiout and one death at Nag Hamadi and another at Esneh. A new plague patient has been admitted to hospital at Mellawi.

div.head: Railway Employes.
div.p: The Railway Administration has been authorised by the Council of Ministers to improve the position of the employes of the Traffic Department and L.E. 6,000 will be expended for this purpose.

div.head: Post Office Savings Bank.
div.p: During last month the number of fresh depositors was 1,320, making a total of 65,435. The total amount deposited last month was L.E. 48,196 and the total sum deposited at the end of last month was L.E. 414,103.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and May 23 481,053 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 264,636 tons were Welsh, 84,091 Newcastle. 80,521 Yorkshire, 24,028 Scotch, and 27,777 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 518,636 tons.

div.head: French v. English in Egypt.
div.p: The recent secondary certificate examination reveals some instructive facts as to the development of English as against French in Egypt. 754 candidates presented themselves for this examination, 91 of whom took French as a subject. Of these 91, there were only 15 successful candidates, one-sixth of the number. The number of candidates successful in English represents seven tenths of the number of candidates.

div.head: Alexandria Engineering Works.
div.p: This company has been formed and has acqiured as a going concern the old established business of Messrs. Wm. Watson and Co. engineers, founders and importers of machinery, etc. The new company takes over all existing contracts in connection with the business, and will complete the orders for work, etc., now in progress. Mr. James Watson has been appointed manager of the Alexandria Engineering Works.

div.head: Typhoid Causation.
div.p: Dr. E.C. Seaton, Medical Officer of Health for Surrey, in his annual report to the Surrey Council devotes a considerable space to examining the causation of typhoid in the county between 1895 and l906, and he has come to the conclusion that it is doubtful whether l0 per cent, of the cases can be said to have been actually caused by the drinking of polluted or infected water supply. He considers that polluted and infected foods are a much more frequent source of typhoid illness than is generally supposed.

div.head: The Mixed Tribunals.
div.p: The Judges of the Mixed Tribunals held a general meeting on Thursday afternoon last at 1.30 p.m. Galilée Orfanelli was proposed for the position of registrar's clerk of the Mixed Tribunals of Mansourah. The following appointments were also confirmed at the meeting : Nicolas Panayotti and Zaki Naggar as preceptors (special class) ; Brunei, Pachel, Aischoulian as copying clerks in Cairo. At the same meeting the distribution of the surplus budget was considered.

div.head: Mex Pumping Station.
div.p: The new boilers of Mex pumping station are expected to arrive at Alexandria from England on the 6th July. They will be ready for the pumping season in October next. The intention of the Public Works Department is to, replace the old boilers entirely, for the present boilers have been working for twenty years. The new boilers will replace four Farcot boilers. Some combustion recorders and water registers are to be fitted up shortly.

div.head: Arab Horse Stamina.
div.p: Mr. Homar Davenport, the American cartoonist, who paid a visit to Syria and Egypt some months ago, makes a hobby of his Arab horses and be acquired some lately from the Bedouins, which have involved him in controversy with Lady Anne Blunt,another devotee of the Arabian horse. Mr. Davenport has lent one of his Arabs, imported from Syria, to the American Government and in order to test the Arabian horse's stamina it is to be ridden from Silverton, Oregon, on the Pacific Coast, to New York, a distance of more than 3,000 miles, by Lieutenant McCabe, at the instance of the War Department. Major-General Beil, the Chief of the Staff, advised the Secretary of War that it would be a useful experiment for gaining data for the improvement of the United States cavalry horse, quoting in his memorandum the example of Lieutenant Basso, of the Russian army, who rode a single horse from Manchuria to St. Petersburg, covering a distance of 5,767 miles in eight months and three days.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellermun liner "Flavian" arrived at Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The S.S. "Cyprian Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 23rd inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 8th June.

div.head: EMPIRE DAY.
CELEBRATION IN LONDON.
ENGLAND AND EGYPT.
div.p: Empire Day has been celebrated in London with more unanimous enthusiasm than ever marked the birthday anniversary of the late Queen Victoria. In the city there was a profusion of flags from all, including the most distant, parts of the earth, and the vast possessions of the British Empire have been on no former occasion so well represented. Prominent among others representing the Empire, the British and Egyptian flags were flying side by side as representing the Sudan.

Our Port Said correspondent states that a number of ships lying in the harbour flew bunting yesterday in honour of Empire Day. Most of the English business houses there flew the Red Ensign. The British Consulate, however, flew no flag.

div.head: THE CROMER MEMORIAL.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-

The letter of "Anxious Spectator" on the subject of the Cromer Memorial shows, as I have reason to believe is the case, that public opinion is far from unanimous in regard to the erection of a hospital for consumptives being a suitable means of commemorating Lord Cromer's work. Would it not be advisable to give intending subscribers the choice of subscribing to one or other memorial, such as a Maternity Home, Tuberculosis Hospital, etc.? Such a plebiscite would discover what exactly is wanted.

div.head: PLANS OF BIZERTA.
ARREST OF STEALERS.
div.p: About two months ago the Minister of Marine at Paris received a communication, with an Egyptian postmark, offering the restitution of stolen plans of Bizerta. A sum of £600 was demanded, otherwise the writer said the plans would he disposed of to a foreign Power. Several detectives were sent to Egypt with the hope of getting into touch with the principals, and two Dutchmen were arrested, and a third-man who is said to be an Englishman. According, however, to the information of the Exchange Telegraph Company all the men arrested in Egypt are Frenchmen.
The "Matin" says that all the papers which were in the hands of the spies, the divulging of which might have had very serious consequences, have been recovered by the authorities.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: The second meeting in regard to the formation of the Syndicate was held yesterday evening at the Alexandria offices of the National Bank of Egypt. No definite decision was arrived at owing to the fact that two of the banks, who are to take part in the Syndicate, have not as yet received instructions from their board of directors in Europe investing them with the authority, without which they cannot participate in the Syndicate.

The meeting consequently could not arrive at any division and it was arranged that another meeting should be held at the National Bank of Egypt at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning, when it is expected that a definite agreement will be arrived at.
We received the following telegram yesterday evening :-
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
Birket el-Sabt, Friday.
We have petitioned Sir Eldon Gorst to save us from perdition resulting from the present crisis in shares, hoping for your assistance. Signed Habib Hanna, Abdul Malak Kiryacos, Bersoum Hanna Meleigh.

div.head: CAFFARI'S CO-OPERATIVE MARKETS, LIMITED.
div.p: The Statuary Meeting of the shareholders of the above company, in conformity with the English Company's Act of 1900, will he held in Cairo on Monday next for the purpose of receiving and considering the report of the directors.

Since its transformation into a company last February and the opening of the markets department, where fresh provisions of all kinds are sold, this business has made remarkable strides and the sales have more than doubled ; averaging at present no less than £13,000 monthly orover £400 daily, whilst in February and March they rose to £15,000 per month. All the leading hotels in the capital have given up dealing with different firms and now procure all their requirements from these central stores. Reckoning the profits already made during the past few months trading and the constantly increasing number of customers, the company will be in a position, so we are informed, to pay a handsome interim dividend in the autumn. Mr. John Caffari, the managing director of this prosperous and well-managed concern, is proceeding to Europe at the end of next month with a view of visiting some of the principal business centres and making arrangements with manufacturers for the supply of goods direct on the most favorable terms.

div.head: THE RAS EL-TIN SPEECHES.
DELAY OF PUBLICATION.
div.p: "It is very remarkable," a correspondent writes, "that both the speeches of the Khedive and Sir Eldon Gorst at the ceremony at Ras el-Tin Palace on Thursday week were telegraphed to London by Reuter's Agency at Cairo on the same day as they were delivered at Alexandria. Yet the speeches did not appear in the local newspapers until the following Saturday." The writer concludes that this either reflects discredit on the enterprise of the newspapers in Egypt or that "political reasons" necessitated the speeches being first telegraphed to London.

We may state that as soon as the ceremony was over we, and our local contemporaries, made an application for copies of the texts of the speeches both to the Alexandria Gouvernorat and the British Consulate at Alexandria. We were informed that no copies of the speeches existed for distribution to the local Press. At that time we were not aware that on that very day copies of the actual speeches had been telegraphed to London, and this tact was not known until the London newspapers of yesterday week arrived by the Brindisi mail. On the day following the ceremony we again applied for a copy of the texts, but were unsuccessful, and it was not until Saturday morning that we received an official intimation from the Alexandria Gouvernorat that the copies of the two speeches were ready for distribution to the local Press. The text of the speeches accordingly appeared in the Alexandrian newspapers published on that Saturday afternoon. Yet they had been communicated to the London newspapers late on Thursday night in order to be published the following morning. The enterprise of the local Press cannot justly be held to be at fault in the matter, for no reporters were admitted to the ceremony at Ras el-Tin Palace and all applications to the authorised official sources for copies of the speeches were met with a strictly "non possnmus" attitude.

Now it is to be noted that there is not the slightest discrepancy between the texts as purported to have been despatched on Thursday from Cairo by Reuters Agency and as communicated to the local newspapers on Saturday. The textual criticism of the Khedive's speech as given in the London papers in English, and as given to the local papers in French, shows that the two versions tally exactly. The speeches, as our readers are aware, are of the ordinary conventional type usual at such ceremonies as the presentation of an exequatur. What then was the reason forthe extraordinary reticence in disclosing the speeches to the local Press, and why had the texts to he first despatched to London ? There is only one conclusion to he drawn and that is that the original text of the speceches had to he sent to England before permission could he obtained for their publication. The telegram was received in London on Thursday and the authorised versions as given to the newspapers in England were sanctioned the same day. The "imprimatur" was then despatched by cubic to Egypt and the identical versions were subsequently given out to the local newspapers. It would be foolish to indulge in any speculations as to whether any reasons of state necessitated certain emendations in the original text. We would deprecate any such surmises, hut on the other hand it is evident that the local Press was not at fault owing to lack of enterprise in this instance. In certain eases official news should not be at once imparted to the newspapers and the authorities are fully justified in such cases in witholding news from the Press, which, if published, might run counter to the interests of the state.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras-el-Tin this morning, where he held a Council of Ministers.
Afterwards his Highness granted a private audiences to several officials who are leaving to- day for Europe.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AND THE OCCUPATION.
div.p: The statements of the Khedive in his recent interview with the correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" to the effect that the British Occupation was preferable to any other leads to the following comments on the part of the "Egyptian Standard" :—

Further, his Highness' remarks concerning the Occupation are certainly justified. He gives it as his personal opinion that he believes the British Occupation is better than would he any other foreign Occupation.

This does not signify of course that he upholds the indefinite prolongation of the Occupation. And certainly, Egypt cannot but declare that a British Occupation is preferable to either a Russian or German Occupation.

div.head: SUDAN PLANTATION SYNDICATE.
div.p: Mr. D.P. MacGillivray has just returned from London, where he has been occupied with the rearrangement of the Sudan Plantation Syndicate, the controlling interest in which it will be remembered he acquired from Mr. Leigh Hunt some months ago. The board of the company is now as follows :— Mr. F. Echstein, of the firm of Wernher Beit and Co. London, Chairman ; Lord Lovat of Beaufort Castle, Bcauly ; Mr. Leigh Hunt, New-York ; Mr. Lionel Phillips of Messrs. Werhner, Beit and Co., London ; and Mr. D.P. MacGillivray, Cairo, managing director. Mr. MacGillivray left last night for the Sudan.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
A POLICY OF SECRET SOCIETIES.
div.p: The Coptic vernacular daily newspaper of Cairo, "Al Watan," published the following article in its issue of yesterday's date :—

We are evidently in bad times. Things that were alien to the Egyptian mind up to a recent date are now the craze in certain quarters and with some persons rushing blindly and heedlessly to their fate. Among the evils formerly unknown, but now, extant in the land is the curse of secret societies reported in our columns this week and referred to in plain terms by some of our confreres, an evil which may spread and lead to the direst of consequences, unless denounced and fought at the outset by all moral and lawful means.

No smoke can ever be without fire, and no news reiterated at intervals and commented upon for years can be without foundation. Our readers may remember that complaints were made of the doings of certain sheikhs or individuals in various parts of the country during the last three years. The complainants always referred to secret meetings and sinister designs, but in every ease of this description the Nationalist Press hastened to contradict the news and inform the public that the persons complained of were the noblest and most innocent of men, and that their secret meetings were actually open and simple from all points of view. Every political or racial agitation was denied as soon as the news came to light, yet the same story crops up every now and then with increased vigour and accumulating evidence of truth. The last story comes from Beni-Suef whither two prominent Nationalist are said to have repaired during the current week and where some stir and suspicion followed in their wake.

The local observers saw in the visit of these two Nationalist leaders from Cairo signs of agitation and have reasons to believe that the deputies preached sedition to the predominant sect in Beni-Suef. If natural or logical deductions can be relied upon in such cases the Beni-Suef correspondents are right in con eluding that a secret society is being formed in Cairo with branches in every city or provincial town with the object of spreading the Nationalist propaganda and strengthening the hand of the persons who are hurling Egypt, into the pit of revolution in search ot power and gain.

While preparing this article for publication we were visited by a friend who has been a careful observer tor years in Upper Egypt and who is an authority on the real condition of the country and the feelings of its people. He is of opinion that secret societies are now being formed in several towns and that a general boycott of all that is British is among their principal aims, Christians in general will suffer if these societies are allowed to spread and grow. Newspapers owned by Nationalists will alone be patronised ; British officials will be as much as possible opposed and persecuted in a subtle and mystic way ; British goods will he discarded and boycotted everywhere ; Europeans in general will he fought in their daily avocations by the combined efforts of the Nationalists in league, and so forth.

This may be an exaggerated picture of the case ; but that secret societies are now Wing formed for purposes detrimental to the cause of reform and to the interests of Christians and foreigners in Egypt there is no doubt. Matters may come to a serious muddle unless firm and strong measures are resorted to by the authorities without delay. Every step taken in advance to prevent the spread of the evil will be more than a hundred steps taken after the storm.

div.head: THE RODOCANACHI ESTATE.
div.p: The latest issue of the Boston "Traveller" contains the following :—

Intimating that he would allow the will, but declaring that he would reserve final decision until he could definitely determine the validity of certain pencil marks on the document, Judge Grant of the probate court this morning handed down a prelimary decision in the will ease of John M. Kodocanuchi, at one time, Greek consul in Boston, and a former wealthy dealer in Oriental goods.

This will, which was contested by his niece, Stella Rodocanachi of Alexandria, Egypt, and a sister, Penelope Rodcanachi of Smyrna, Turkey, on the grounds that the testator was of unsound mind when he made the will, brought out a very knotty problem the question being whether or not certain pencil marks on the codicil of the will constitute a cancellation of the provision. This question the court has under consideration.

Rodocanachi, who was considered quite wealthy when he died last September, left many public bequests, among the most important being $100,000 to the Museum of Fine Arts, $100 each to the Rev. Edward Everett Hall, the Kindergarten for the Blind in Jamaica Plain and the Winchester Home for Aged Women in Charlestown, $200 to the Greek Church of Boston, and $8,000 each to Eva Jellieal School and the Scharalambor Hospital in Smyrna, Turkey.

div.head: THE LATE SYDNEY CARVER.
div.p: According to news received from England Mr. Sydney H. Carver died from diphtheria. He arrived at Liverpool from America very ill and, it is believed, succumbed the same night The Alexandria Bonded Stores has given £5 to the Rudolph Home and £5 to the British Benevolent Society in memory of the late Sydney H. Carver.

div.head: HAMBURG & ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE CO.
ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company was held at Cairo yesterday afternoon, when the following report of the hoard of directors was unanimously adopted :—

In submitting their seventh annual report and balance sheet to the shareholders, the directors although satisfied with the business of the company iu general, have to report that owing to unforeseen causes, the profits of the company have been somewhat less than last year. An unfortunate accident to the machinery of the Victoria prevented her from sailing on her last voyage, when her passenger list was practically full, and beyond this, owing to the late commencement of the tourist season, the earlier boats were by no means full. Also there have been no profits to show from investments which last year amounted to a considerable sum.

The competition on all sides has rendered this branch of the company's business the least profitable ; rates have now been cut down to the lowest possible figure consistent with running on a paying basis. The conditions now existing must equally affect all other competing companies and by the policy of cutting rates the public alone benefit. The experiment in connection with the employment of sailing barges has not been a success, chiefly owing to the difficulty of controlling the time spent on each voyage, the native crews preferring, while drawing regular pay, to loiter on the way. The directors are now considering the best means of dealing with the situation.

The investments appear in the balance sheet at cost price. Owing to the crisis through which the share market has recently past the shares of the Crédit Foncier and the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Co. show a loss which is partly compensated for by the appreciation in value of the shares of the Alexandria Bond oil Warehouse Co. In accordance with the advice of the auditors the depreciation in value only is shown and is debited against the reserve fund, whilst the appreciation in value of the shares of the Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co., is not taken into account.
Hamburg-Amerika Linie.

This agreement has resulted, as was to be expected, in a considerable increase in the bookings in Europe and America and therein every reason to believe that the coming season will fully justify the agreement with this influential company. A further arrangement has been come to by which the Hamburg-Amerika Linie will in future carry out all bookings whether in Egypt or other countries, an arrangement which will effect an economy in the present system of joint bookings.
New Workshops.

The new worshops at Shoubra are nearing completion and it is hoped that when the company's worshops at Boulac are transferred to Shoubra, some 4,000 metres at Boulac, which have the advantage of a good frontage on the river with deep water alongside, can he sold at a very handsome profit. This appreciation is not taken into account in the balance sheet and the Boulac laud is shown at it cost price of only P.T. 50 per metre. An offer of £5 per metre was received but the directors did not feel justified in accepting it. Shareholders must remember that the capital of the company has been increased from £120,000 to £140,000, whilst the two new steamers "Nubia", and "Germania" have not yet developed their full earning power. The accident to the "Victoria" in the height of the season seriously reduced the profits.
Dividend.
The directors propose paying a dividend of 5 1/2% and carrying forward a balance of L.E. 561.55K mm.

After making provision for depreciation (the same in each year) and maintenance (which has been considerably reduced) there remains to he distributed on this season's working alone, a sum of: L.E. 6,357.436
from which the directors propose to pay a dividend of 4%: 5,460.000
Leaving a balance of: L.E. 897.436
To reserve account: ,, 98.743
Brought forward from last year: 1,801.365
Supplementary dividend of 1 ½ %: 2,047.500
Carried forward to Profit and Loss Account for next year: L.E. 561.558

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Sirdar is arriving at Alexandria in the second week in June and will leave by the Austrian Lloyd steamer for Trieste on the 15th proxo.

Count de Serionne and party, having crossed Menzaleh Lake yesterday morning from Fort Suid to Matarieh, accompanied thence by Baron E.G. Rey, arrived at Mansourah by the 4.28 p.m. train, and drove direct to the river, where they embarked on the dahabieh "Ariadne" towed by a steam tug. They continued their journey down stream to Dakahla for the purpose of visiting the states of The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Co. Ltd. During their stay they will be the guests of the director of this estate.

Those familiar with the history of the Sudan campaigns will remember the extraordinary tenderness Mr. John Morley once showed and must now regret—for the Khalifa, which led to Lord St. Aldwin nicknaming him "The False Prophet of the Sudan." The influence of office is very great and the whiledom supporter of the Khalifa is now sternly repressing sedition in India.
We regret to announce the death of the grandmother of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, who died at Cairo ou Thursday at the age of 85 years.

Mr. E. Farrely has replaced Mr. Simpson as manager of the Medinet el-Fayomu branch of the National Bank of Egypt during that gentleman's service at Port Said where he temporarily replaces Mr. de Rougemont.

div.head: ROWING ON THE NILE.
div.p: We, on taking up our abode in a strange country, naturally look round to see what chance we have of pursuing our favourite sports, and we generally manage to satisfy ourselves in one form or another. The rowing man, however, on coming to Egypt finds that there is no facility to continue what is at the same time one of the finest and healthiest of English sports. He has been told probably before leaving the Thames, or whatever river he has done his rowing on, that the Nile is not at all adapted to his form of sport ; he is threatened with certain death by drowning should he venture on its waters ; he is told that no light boat can live in this same water ; and that even if she could, the acids in the water of the Nile would soon perish her, should she otherwise survive.

That all this is a fallacy those who have tried are willing and able to show, and in a country where so many different forms of sport are indulged in, and where exercise is essential from a health point of view, it seems a great pity that so fine a sport as rowing should not find its place. We know Indian rivers become impossible at some times of the year, and in this respect the Nile is no exception. When the river is in flood no waterman would venture on it in a racing craft, but at other times the writer fails see that it presents much greater difficulties than other rivers. What could he more perfect from rowing man's point of view than the Nile as we sometimes see it now, veritably as calm as the proverbial mill pond ? It cannot be denied that at times, when the wind blows from the North, the Nile then becomes sufficiently rough to seriously damage a light boat, unless the greatest care is used in manipulating it, but when this is the case we have the Bahr-el-Aamah to which we can retire in comfort. The winter has never yet seen this branch too rough to practise on, and should it ever become so,, which is doubtful, there is still another reach more sheltered than the latter where the oarsman and sculler may seek refuge, and that is the stretch of water between Rodah Island and the mainland.

As regards the destruction properties of the acids of the Nile, after ten weeks of use, the racing boats, which the writer has now on the Nile; have begun to show no signs of damage from this cause and provided ordinary care is taken of them there is no reason that they should; no doubt were they left in this water they would soon perish, but this would happen anywhere.

div.head: THREATENING THE PATRIARCH.
div.p: His Holiness Photius, the (Ecumenical Patriarch of Alexandria, recently received a letter ordering him to pay £500 to the Bulgarian-Macedonian Revolutionary Committee at Sofia and threatening in case of non-compliance to blow up the whole Patriarchate ! His Holiness has sent the letter to the Governor of Alexandria.

The definite results of the elections after the ballots are as follows:— 84 socialists, 66 antisemites, 24 German liberals, 25 German people party, 18 German radicals, 31 clericals, 22 Young Turks, 18 agrarian Germans, 5 old Zcheks, 33 agrarian Slates, 24 Slovenians. Mr. Eppingey chief of the Bohemian Germans, has been beaten. (Havas)
The second ballots have been concluded. The new Reichsrath will comprise 21 parties, the strongest of which, the Socialists, number 82. The Antisémites have 66 representatives. (Reuter)
400 men of the Cameron Highlanders have arrived in the East Hand, 200 of the Bonier Regiment in the West Rand, and 200 of the Queens Bays are marching to Johannesburg.(Reuter)
It is understood that the Government regards the Irish bill as dead and will now push the English Allotments bill which Mr. Harcourt will introduce on Monday. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN EMPIRE COUNCIL.
THE TSAR'S REMARK.

div.p: The Tsar, acknowledging a loyal telegram received from the Council of the Empire, says "My life is not precious to me provided that Russia lives in the glory of peace and prosperity." (Reuter)
The Diet opened yesterday. It includes 19 women members. (Reuter)
The german gunboat Luchs has left in order to render assistance to the Chanzy, (Reuter)

The "Frankfort Gazette" announces that in July or August a discussion will take place, probably at Hamburg, between British and German delegates on the subject of the load water-lines of vessels adopted in Germany and Britain. It is hoped that the discussion will lead to an understandig and that the existing difference will lie considerably modified. (Reuter)

The American explorer, Mr. Wellman, will sail for Spitzberg on the 15th June, from where ie will start in a mammoth airship for the Pole at the end of July. The airship carries a dozen men besides boats, sledges, dogs and provisions for 10 months. (Reuter)
The Budget Commission has been nominated. Mr. Berteaux has been unanimously elected president. (Havas)

div.head: EGYPT'S NEGLECTED CHILDREN.
div.p: Egypt has a large number of neglected children. They are not of one race, nor are their parents of one religion. But as there are many more Moslems than others in Egypt, so are there more neglected Moslems than other children. Many of the leading philanthropic men who are interested in the poor have thought that something should be done for such neglected outcasts. It is proposed to gather them into homes, feed, clothes, and educate them, and give them a means of livelihood. The classes from which selections will be made are :—orphans, children of the destitute poor, reformatory children, children of criminals.

A preliminary step in all such schemes has been the erection of temporary shelters or night refuges at which a morning meal is given to those who have lodged the night, with a labour yard attached to the refuge, where those benefited are able to make a return for the expense incurred. The advantages of these refuges in the early stages of such work as is contemplated is that vagrant children can be registered and classified, some being returned to relatives, and only the worst eases kept for the permanent homes.

It is fully believed that this scheme, thus briefly outlined, will have the national support. As a commencement and nucleus the Government have expressed their willingness to hand over the present orphanage at Boulac to the society, provided that the waifs sent by the authorities are accepted, even for temporary housing. (Communicated by the Ragged School Union and Shaftesbury Society).

div.head: SUBORDINATE SERVICE EXAMINATION.
SHIBIN EL KOM SUCCESSES.
div.p: Shibin el Kom, Thursday.

The pass list of the above Governmentexamination arrived this morning. About 750 candidates sat for the examination, of whom 463 passed, i.e. 63 % The following list, gives the percentage of passes obtained by the five most successful schools :
El-Massai El Mashkoura Shibin El Kom. 94.%
Tewfikieh. Cairo. 85.%
Saidieh. Cairo. 84.%
Khedivieh. Cairo. 81.%
Ras El Tin. Alexandria. 76.%
The above result is very gratifying to the pupils and teachers of the Shibin El Kom School as it is the first time the school has entered any pupils for an examination above the primary standard.

The secondary section was opened only in October 1905, with the following staff : Director, Ibrahim Bey Fahmy ; Teacher of Arabic, Sheikh Ahmed Iraif ; Teacher of English, Mr. Lewis ; Teacher of Mathematics and Sciences, Mr. Keene , Teacher of Translation, Mohamed Effendi Shiati.
The staff and pupils are to be congratulated on the excellent result obtained at their first efiort.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: It is officially intimated that Lieutenant Colonels J. J. Asser, and RE. Bernard, C M.G., have been granted the local rank of Colonel whilst employed with the Egyptian Army.
On promotion, Captain Symes, D.S.O.,Hampshire Regiment, remains with the Egyptian Army.

Captains W. R. Thompson and W.A.C. Kinsman, D.S.O., Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, just promoted to that rank are employed as the adjutants of the 1st Cinque Ports V.R.C., Hastings, and the 3rd V.B. King's Liverpool Regiment, Southport, respectively. Both got their commissions in the Inniskillings in April, 1900, and both were with the 2nd Battalion in the closing stages of the war in the Transvaal, and Captain Thompson was wounded in the action of Petersburg, where the Inniskillings made one of the finest charges of the war. Captain Thompson received the Queen's medal with three clasps, and was mentioned in despatches, and Captain Kinsman, who had served previously with the 1st Battalion in Natal, and was badly wounded was mentioned in despatches and received the D.S.O., Queen's medal with three clasps and the King's medal with three clasps.

The new organisation of the troops came into force yesterday throughout the United Kingdom. Under it, the army is poorer by some 10,000 men and not the slightest thing has been done to make it more efficient

The death has just taken place at Bath of Colonel G.V. Fosberry, V.C., whilst he was visiting some relatives. He earned the little cross "For Valour" in the Umbeyla Expedition, 1863, whilst a volunteer attached to the 1st Punjab Infantry, his own regiment having been the late 4th European Regiment. It was after the handful of British troops defending the Crag Piquet had been killed or driven in that an attempt was made to recapture it, and in again carrying the position with a few men of the Punjabis, Fosberry displayed the greatest gallantry, and at a subsequent period he pursued the routed enemy with great loss, and that at a time when a British repulse would have been disastrous.

With a view to the avoidance of illegalities in connection with the proceedings of courts martial the Army Council has issued instructions to be laid down before all courts martial when assembled. The points to which attention is particularly directed are (a)—Members of courts martial in cases of desertion must not have previously served on the Court of Inquiry on illegal absence, upon which the charge of desertion is founded, (b)—Men mast not be charged under the 32nd Section of the Army Act when the offence is one which comes under the 33rd Section (c)—Care most be taken that members of the Court have not less than the regulated service, (d) — Trial of men exempt under the 101st Section of the Army Act, which limits the offences for which a soldier can be tried after three years from the date of the offence, to those of mutiny, desertion, or fraudulent enlistment.

Following the prohibition of "The Mikado," the Home Secretary has issued instructions to the local authorities to draw the attention of managers of theatres, music halls, and circuses the undesirability of permitting on the stage anything calculated to cast ridicule on the wearers of his Majesty's uniform, or which may have a tendency to affect recruiting. This is straining at the gnat and swallowing a camel when a full blown agency is at work in Ireland to prevent Irishmen from joining the army and navy, and the local authorities there seem to be asleep.

The cruiser Seylla, which was recently engaged in carrying reliefs to the Mediterranean and other stations, has been selected for additional service on the North America and West Indies station. This is the outcome of the recent Jamaican troubles and the rioting at St. Lucia, where the civil police were unable to cope with the rioters.

div.head: AN INTERESTING FIND.
div.p: Sir Norman Lockyer's investigations of stone circles put back Phoenician influence in Britain to a very early period, but material proofs of intercourse between Europe and this island are few Mr. W. Dale showed at the Royal Society's Soirée a cordoned bucket or cist of bronze which affords a fairly definite proof that such intercourse existed as early as 700 B.C. The bucket is of North Italian manufacture, and is similar to specimens found at Halstatt and in other parts of Europe as far as Hanover, but never before in Britain. It has quite recently been proved that some brooches which are in museums and in private hands, and which have been found in England, must have come from North Italy in the Early Iron Age of Europe. The bronze bucket which was found at Weybridge last month while a shaft was being sunk for the purposes of the very modern invention of a motor track confirms this theory of a 3,000 year old British commerce in a remarkable way.

div.head: K. S. C.

A match was played at Ghezireh on Tuesday 21st, the Egyptian Army and Gunners having challenged a team of the Coldstream Guards.
After a close but rather slow game the Guards won by 1 goal.

div.head: THE WORLD'S MOTOR-CARS.
div.p: "It is interesting to estimate the total sum of motor-cars of all kinds being used all over the world at the present moment," says Lord Montague in the 4 "Car." "After careful consideration I put forward in round numbers the following figures :—America, 90,000 ; Great Britain, 75,000 ; France, 30,000 ; Germany, 20,000 ; Austria and Hungary, 8000 ; Italy, 6000 ; Spain, 4000 ; other countries of Europe, including Russia, 5000 ; India, 2000 ; Egypt, Canada, Australia, and other British colonies, 2000 ; Central and Southern America, 1000 ; China, Japan, aud Eastern Asia, 500—amounting to 248,500 vehicles in all. It may be a surprise to some people to notice that the United States comes out at the head of the list and France only third. It is also a startling fact that there are about two-thirds as many cars registered in London as in the whole of France."

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
Coton.
div.p: On nous boude pour notre derniere revue, re qui nous est parfaitement égal, d'autant plus que nous nous y attendions un peu ; mais ce qui ne saurait nous laisser indifférents, ee Mint les eritiques acerbes qui nous ont été décochées. Celles-là nous ont causé un plaisir réel, ear elles nous ont fourni la preuve que ce que nous avions écrit Samedi passé était juste rt basé,sans tjuoi on se serait contenté de jeter le journal au panier en haussant les épaules. Mais ce qui est heureux encore, c'est que ces manifestations de mauvaise humeur, intern pestiveset faisant le ridicule soient restées isolées et confinées à une seule personne qui, il va à leine rois ou quatre semaines, trouvait que nous étions clairvoyant, sublimes dans nos idées et ne jurait, en pleine corlieille, que par nos admirables revues ! Seulement, à côté de ceci, nous avons eu la satisfaction de constater que les autres composants du petit groupe haussier auquel nous avons fait allusion, et qui avaient été moins exubérants, jadis dans leurs témoignages d'amitié, ont pris la chose du hou côté, comme d'ailleurs ils devaient le taire, et quelquesuns ont meme eu le hou sens de venir discuter nos opinions en tête à tête avec nous.
Mais, passons outre et occupons-nous maintenant du marché.

La première séance de la semaine qui a été tenue mardi, à cause de le suspension d'affaires des deux journées précédentes, a été en tous points défavorable au parti de la hausse petites exportations, manque d'acheteurs sérieux et. calme en Amérique, tout a concouru puiir peser sur le marché et nous valoir un recul de 1/4 de tallari sur le Novembre et 11 32 sur le Juillet, Comme on le voit, ce jour lu c'est la vieille récolte qui était offerte et ce fait continuait absolument nos idées.

Au fond, jusque-là, il n'y avait rien d'extraordinaire, mais c'est au début de la séance du lendemain que les choses ont semblé vouloir aller au plus mal : les haussiers mêmes cherchaient à passer leurs jmquets à d'autres et on ne trouvait plus d'acheteurs, ce qui, à un moment donné, s'est traduit par une nouvelle baisse de 1 4 pour la vieille récolte et 5/32 pour le Novembre. Heureusement pour les haussiers, une demande importante et inattendue nous est venue du Caire et si pour la matinée même elle n'a pas eu tout l^eftet que les acheteurs en espéraient, il n'en est pas moins vrai quelle a suffi pour enrayer le mouvement retrograde et produire une reprise de 8/8 2 à fe 82 suivant les mois. Cette bonne tendance s'est affirmée encore davantage hier, les nouveaux efforts du Caire, secondés par ceux d'Alexandrie, ayant abouti an résultat île faire monter le Novembre de 1/4 de tallari et le Juillet de 8/10, ce qui fait que le résumé des fluctuations de la semaine consiste en 1/10 de baisse pour la nouvelle et 1/4 pour l'ancienne récolte.

Nous ne voulons pas déjà chanter victoire pour nos opinions, car nous verrons encore maints changements d'ici l'échéance Juillet ; mais, en attendant, noussoinmesen droit de constater, n'en déplaise à ceux qui nous regardent de travers, que dans un laps de temps de trois jours seulement le Juillet est tombé à 1/32 au-dessous, du Novembre. Nous étions donc dans le vrai en préconisant cette éventualité piancl le déport était de 1 tallari, et nous y resterons aujourd'hui en soutenant que le report, qui existe actuellement, ne peut que seaccentuer de jour en jour jusqu'à atteindre 12 tallari au moins. Quant à l'effet que jareille situation pourra avoir sur l'avenir des prix, cela dépendra des circonstances ; mais jxiiirce qui est de relation ou de rapport de réroi te à récolte, ce n'est que à la condition que le Juillet offre un avantage réel et matériel que l'on trouvera des amateurs pour le prendre, quitte à ceux-ci tie donner du Novembre en échange s'ils le jugent convenable.

Certes, il y a toujours l'imprévu qui peut à tout instant modifier la fufon de voir et même la situation, mais il va de soi que quand on raisonne sur une chose, on se base, non sur les possibilités qui peuvent survenir, mais sur les faits constatés du moiueqt. Aussi, et pour cette raison que guise de réponse à ceux qui cherchaient à chauffer le marché avec la soidisant opinion câblée par une maison de Liverpool, considérée parles intéressés comme formant autorité en ce «pii concerne les cotons d'Egypte et comprise dans les rangs des modérés, nous reproduisons, sans commentaires, que cette maison même écrivait en date du hu courant. Le marché est de nouveau lourd lens intérêt pour les cotons égyptiens et la filature ne montre que peu d'inclination aux achats, excepté pour ses besoins immédiats qui semblent fort petits, étant donné que, toute apparonce, elle s'est couverte pour ses futurs besoins éloignés, ce qui fait que, comme conséquence, elle ne viendra au marché que quer des petitesses pour combler des petits besoins."

N'y a-t-il pas quelque différence entre la réalité écrite et l'information qu'on lui attribuait la filature anglaise étaient anxieuse d'acheter de l'Egyptien. Etsi l'on admet que la maison en question est au courant de la situation vraie, nous nous demandons un peu que fond doiton faire sur l'assertion que les besoins de la consommation sont encore grands pour le restant de la campagne et qu'il nous absorberont toutes nos ressources.
Soyons logiques pour le moins !

D'autre part, nous ne voulons par exagerer les choses et nous reconnaissons que la filature pourra nous prendre tout le solde encore disponible de notre recolte ; mais, jusqu'a preuve du contraire, nous ne demorderons pas de l'opinion, comme dit plus haut, qu'elle ne le fera que si elle trouve avantage effectif, soit qu'elle le fasse sous forme d'achats purs et simples, soit sous forme d;echange avec du Novembre.

Pour revenir au marché, nous dirons que dans les trois jours qui ont constitué la semaine commerciale cette fois, on ne pouvait naturellement guère faire autant d'affaires que dans une semaine complète; malgré tout,cependant, l'activité, dans son ensemble, a été assez satisfaisante, surtout pour le Novembre dont la tenue, comme on la d jà vu, a été plus régulière et plus ferme que celle du Juillet.
La dernière filière Mai a été insignifiante, quelques milliers de can tara à peine qui ont servi à liquider la position du mois. Les der niers reports faits^hici ont été combinés sur la base de 9/16.

Le seul fait intéressant et qui piéoecupe actuellement tons les esprits chez nous est la continuation de la haussé sur les américains. Où cela s'arrêtera-til, personne ne s tirait le dire, car, après tout, le marché est pour le moment entièrement entre les mains d'outsiders qui trouvent qu'il faut acheter du coton, sans savoir le pourquoi et le comment et qui finiront par nous offrir le spectahle d'un sauve qui peut comme il n'y en a jamais eu !

Ce n'est pas là une appréciation à nous, mais bien le résumé de ce que des maisons à Liverpool, qui ont prévu la hausse, n'ont pu s'empêcher décrire, eu ajoutant (pie la filature reste indiff rente à toutes ces manipulations et que la clique Price, qui a eu toutes les chances pour elle cette fois, n'a pas hésité à profiter déTtycasioii pour vendre du Juillet. Ht en cela olle a été suivie aussi par d'autres faiseurs qui espèrent ht réaction d'un jour à l'autre. En attendant, nous n'en sommes pas à ee point 7 ; au contraire, cost la hausse qui persiste.

Notre marché du disponible a été plutôt inactif, mais feripe : certaines qualités sont difficiles à acheter, même à la pleine cote du jour. La seule demande saillante «pii a existé a porté sur les cotons bas.

Quant aux prix, la cote officielle établie ce matin les donne connue invariables sur la semaine dernière, pour tous les genres et classements, et cela en dépit de la baisse du Juillet qui aurait du former la hase pour la fixation de prix. Les exportations ont fini par être une petite désillnsioil avec leur total, resté inférieur aux prévisions, de 6600 Balles, contre 7700 Balles l'année passée.
On a parlé de suspens et de retard en Douane, mais le chiffre pour la journée d'aujourd hui qui est de l ion Balles environ indiquerait, qu'il n'y a rien d'important de ee côté-là.

Pour la semaine prochaine chacun y va de sa prophétie, mais somme toute personne ne connaît quoi que ce soit. Toutefois, les probabilités semblent être pour une quantité modérée, det à peu près dans les chiffres de la semaine qui vient de finir, à opposet aux 10,000 halles environ de 1906 pour la période correspondante. Avec, ces quantités probables nous arriverons aux environs de 55,000 halles comme total dir mois. O'est énorme pour Mai, mais bien au-dessous des 80,000 halles qu'on préconisait et auxquelles quelques ans avaient fini par sérieusement croire.

Liverpool n'a pas montré beaucoup de bonnes dispositions pour les égyptiens disponibles avec des ventes de halles en tout pour les trois journées de mardi à jeudi. Par contre, pour ce qui est des pris, it y a du soutien, le spot étant toujours coté à 10 6/16, tandis que les futurs juin inscrivent en hausse de 7/64 au niveau de 10 10/64.

Lés Américains aussi ont été peu actifs, mais cela n'étonne personne pour la semaine de la Pentecôte ! Seulement cette oisiveté n'a pas empêché les cours de monter et c'est sur lu cote de 7.10 pour le spot, 6.53 pour le Juillet-Août et 6.28 pour l'Octobre-Novembre que la clôture d'hier a eu lieu, ce qui fait respectivement 14, 20 et 22 points de hausse.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: Les arrivages de la semaine peuvent passer pour une surprise à cause de leur importance, mais sur ce point nous nous sommes déjà expliqués et il a pas lifeu duir revenir.
En tous cas, sur les quantités reçues il n'y avait qu'une faible partie destinée à la vente et elle a constamment obtenu de pleins prix. La dernière cote de ce matin a été de P.T. 89.
Les exportations, quoique n'ayant pas atteint les prévisions, ont deus quand même énormes avec leur total de 93000 Ardebs.

Pour la semaine prochaine il n'y aura pas beaucoup d'embarquements, ce qui ne peut qu'être considéré comme une circonstance heureuse avec peu marchandise qui nous reste pour nous mener jusque à la fin de la saison.
En contrats, presque point d'affaires et le Juin finit à P.T, 2 1/2 au-dessous de la semaine passée, la ertfe étant de P.T. 89 1/2.
Hull aussi est plus caltfie à £8.12/6 sans demande.
La réaction semble naturelle après toute la "furia" que nous avons nie et qu'il y ait eu accaparement d'huile et égorgement, tout a une fin. Quand même, nous resterons dans les hauts prix.
Les 3 mois Nov-Janvier sont inactifs et cotés à P.T. 70.
L'Angleterre n'en parle pas.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Après une baisse violente, conséquence d'allègements précipités,les valeurs égyptiennes montrent depuis deux jours un pou plus de fermeté sur les places européennes.

Ici, le marché est de plus en plus mauvais. Très rares sont les titres qui n'enregistrent [ms cette semaine de très sensibles moins-values. Les excès de la spéculation d'antan rendent encore nécessaires des liquidations qui n'ont pu jusqu'ici s'effectuer faute de contre parties sérieuses.

Il est inutile de se le dissimuler, le marché ne reprendra pas son allure normale, tant qu'il ne sera pas complètement assaini. Il faut que les bonnes tendances de la place ne soient pas entravées. Aussi enregistrons-nous avec une réelle satisfaction les efforts tentés tant ici qu'au Caire dans le but de relever le marché par l'absorption du Hot tant. Un d'abord sollicité f assistance du Gouvernement, mais Sir Hlduii Gorsta répondu aux délégués, qui étaient allé l'entretenir, qu'il ne voyait pas dans la situation actuelle des motifs suffisants pour justifier l'intervention. Il a, toutefois, assuré la Commission que le Gouvernement suivrait avec sympathie leurs efforts en vue d'améliorer la situation. Indépendamment des demarches faites auprès du gouvernement et sur l'initiative de plusieurs personnalités du monde de la finance, il s'est constitué un syndicat, lequel s'est assuré le concours de la National Bank, à l'effet d'enrayer la baisse. On espère réunir pour constituer ce Consortium un capital de 1 million de livres (la moitié est déjà souscrite). Cette somme servirait de marge pour l'achat de titres pour une valeur de 4 à 5 millions de livres environ. La réunion des financiers tenue eet après midi à la National Bank n'a [iris aucune décision, la plupart des Banques n'ayant pas encore reçu d'instructions de la part de leur Conseil d'Admimstration d'Europe.
Une dernière réuiiiun sera tenue dimanche prochain à 11 heures.

Suivant certains renseignements que nous avons obtenu l'achat du flottant s'effectuerait par la publication d'une liste de valeurs de 1er ordre avec les prix relatifs en annonçant que le syndicat achète au comptant ces valeurs sans limitation aucune do leur nombre.
Le projet est, comme on le voit, excellent et nous espérons le voir bientôt mettre en exécution dans l'intérêt du pays.

Cette semaine nous avons assisté à une très vive reculade de cours. La National Banket la Reliera baissent d une livre à 22 11/16 et 32 respectivement, l'obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier Egyptien retrograde de lu francs à 317 et la nouvelle de 4 francs à 266 T Agricole et l'Union foncière perdent 1/8 à 8 3/4 et 5 3/16 respectivement. Aux cours actuels ces titres constituent un placement avantageux. La Banque d'Orient paie son tribut à la baisse générale et recule de 2 francs. La Sait and Soda faiblit à 18 6 en perte 6 pence. La Banque d Athènes et les Tram que les comptes qui seront soumis à l'Assemblée Générale feront ressortir un bénéfice net supérieur à 1,500,000 francs. C'est pour un capital de 12,500,000 fr„ et pour un premier exercice un résultat fort satisfaisant. Ives parts des jouissance des Eaux - du Caire continuent à dégringoler à cause de la nouvelle émission ; étant donnée la situation actuelle de la place, cette opération est accueillie avec surprise.

On a traité la Sidi Salem à £2 1/2. Comme il était aisé de le prévoir, les cours élevés auxquels la spéculation avait porté certains titres n'ont pu être maintenus, le bon sens finissant toujours par reprendre ses droits à la Bourse. On a échangé également les Ltinghis à 11/16, l'Arditi à 3/4, le Comptoir à 4 livres, les Estates à 1 5/16, l'United Land à 11/16 les ltitz Hotels à 1 livre 1/4 et la Delta Land à 2 1/2. A propos de cette dernière Société nous apprenons de bonne source qu'un dividende de 2 sh. 6 d. sera déclaré pour l'exercice écoulé. En outre les bénéfices actuellement réalisés pour l'exercice en cours permettent déjà de fixer un dividende intérimaire de 3 sch. dont le paiement aura lieu en Septembre prochain.

Les actionnaires de la société Ghézireh Mansions, Ltd., se sont réunis lundi dernier en assemblée générale air Caire : le conseil d'administration a présenté un rapport sur la situation de la société, mettant ainsi les actionnaires en état d'avoir une notion exacte des opérations faites jusqu'à ce jour, avant de commencer la construction de villas et magasins sur le terrain de 10,000 mètres carrés de la société avait acheté aux Egyptian Hotels, Ltd., au prix do £13 le mètre carré, avec le droit de pouvoir construire uussi, comme nous venons de dire, des magasins, ce de les Egyptian Hotels n'ont permis à aucun autre acquéteur de terrain.

M. Antoine Lasciac, l'ingénieur-conseil de la société, ayant préparé les plans et les devis des nouvelles constructions, les actionnaires en ont également pris connaissance. L'entreprise sera confiée, à la Industrial Building et Commercial Company of Egypt. Les Ghézireh Mansions ont acheté, tout dernièrement, deux nouvelles parcelles de terrain d'une superficie de 2400 mètres carrés, ainsi que la villa Albert qui a environ 2000 m. c. Le terrain est situé à proximité de la promenade de Ghézireh et la villa tout près de la grotte.

Du rapport de la Société Foncière d'Egypte, qui vient d'être publié, il ressort que le montant total des ventes de terrains s'est élevé, depuis la constitution de la société à 11.742 feddans, pour une soiqtne de L.E. 424,468, sur laquelle il a été encaissé L.E. 380,001 à fin décembre 1906,. laissant un solde de L.E. 443,467.
Au 31 décembre 1906, les recettes de toutes natures se sont élevées à L.E. 50,807, et les dépenses à L.E. 29,182, laissant un excédent de recettes de L.E. 21,625.
Les bénéfices nets sur ventes de terres se sont élevés en 1906 à L.E. 36,860. Le total des bénéfices dont la société peut disposer est de L.E. 58,486.
Mais les bénéfices de l'exercice 1906 et le rapport des bénéfices de 1905, s'élèvent ensemble à L.E. 144,209 et ont été répartis comme suit :

Réserve statutaire L,H. 1,297, dividende aux actions de £ 1 10 sh. par action de £ 15, soit L.E. 21,206 ; distribution de £ 5 sur le montant versé de chaque action L.E, 70,687 ; bénéfices exclusivement acquis aux actions et reporté à nouveau L.E. 48,689 ; Conseil d'administration L.E. 2,329 ; soit un total de L.E. 144,209.
La réserve statutaire se trouve portée à L.E. 19,500, telle qu'elle est fixée par l'article 38 des statuts.

Nous avons reçu le rapport du Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris approuvé le 9 avril écoulé. D'après ce rapport, au 31 décembre 1906, le montant de la situation était de 6 milliard 211 millions au 31 décembre 1905.
Celui des Effets entrés en portefeuille a été, au cours de l'exercice, de 14 milliards 510 millions, au lieu de 13 milliards 114 millions en 1905.

Le rapport annonce que l'Agence d'Alexandrie, de fondation récente, réalise les espérances et que le conseil d'administration a poursuivi son programme d'expansion eu Egypte en créant une Agence au Caire.

Après déduction de tons frais et charges, et larges amortissements, les résultats de l'exercice 1906 autorisent une répartition de 30 francs par action. 11 a été distribué le 31 janvier l'acompte habituel de 12 fr. 50 c. On répartira encore le 31 juillet prochain, 17 fr. 50 c. sous déduction de l'impôt résultant des lois de finances. Les parts de fondateur recevront, sous lu même déduction, 7 fr. 30, et il sent porté à nouveau 378,549 fr. 86 centimes.

Le rapport dit encore que les actionnaires apris avoir entendu le rapport du conseil d administration, ceux de la Commission de contrôle et des Commissaires, ont approuvé les comptes de l'exercice 1906, tels qu'ils ont été présentés et détaillés, et arrêté, en conséquence à la somme de 9,807,604 fr. 74 c. le solde créditeur du compte Profits et Pertes.
L'Assemblee reeliy M.M. Jules Rostand et de Sincay, administrateurs sortants et M. Robert membre de la Commission permanante.

div.head: PERUNA
div.p: SUFFERED FOR YEARS WITH A COMPLICATION OF PELVIC DISEASES.

Read the Letters of Gratitude From Women Who Have Been Benefited By Dr. Hartman's Advice.
A Multitude of Such Letters Are Received Every Year.
A TYPICAL LETTER.
Mrs. Carry Peduzzt, Llostad, N. Dak., writes :
"I take pleasure in telling you that through your wonderful medicine I am entirely cured of catarrh of the stomach and pelvic organs.
"I was so rundown ou account of my illness that I could no longer attend to my housework. I could not eat or sleep and had terrible pain in my back.
"I took Peruna and in five months I was well. I have not felt so well for a long time.
"I wish everyone who is sick would take Peruna and thus recover their health.
"I have Peruna tn the house continually. I thank you for all that you have done for me."
A Medicine of Merit.
Mist Katie A. Washer, 1706 Prentice street, Louisville, Ky., writes:
"As my experience has been so favorable from the use of Peruna, I unhesitatingly state that I believe that it is a medicine of unquestioned merit for all the ills that we women suffer from.
"I find that it strengthens and infuses new life into the system, and whenever I feel rundown or over tired, a few doses of Peruna will strengthen me again."
Found a Friend In Need— Peruna. Mrs. Florence Aitkens, 1104 Front St., Toledo, Ohio, writes :
"Peruna cured me of catarrh the uterus. I took about four bottles when I noticed an improvement and five bottles cured me.
"I do not know what I would have been like to-day had I not obtained Peruna, for I was in a terrible state.
"I had pains all over and was cross and irritable. I was losing hope of ever being well again.
"I am to-day a well woman after suffering for nine months. I cannot tell you bow happy I feel, but you will know.
"Peruna is the best medicine on earth. "My husband is now taking it and I will always keep Peruna in my house.
"Peruna is the best friend I ever had. It cured me."
America Is the Land of Nervous Women.
The majority of women are nervous because they suffer from some form of pelvic catarrh.
The greatest obstacle in the way of recovery is that they do not understand that catarrh is the main source of their illness.
Women who are in doubt as to their ailments should write to Dr. Hartman, President of The Hartman Hanitarium, Columbus, Ohio, who will give their letters prompt attention, without charge.
Miss Anna McGinn, 161 Plain street, Providence, R. I., writes:
"I wish to let you know of the good your medicine has done for me.
"I had what the doctors called heart trouble. I had been doctoring for a year before I tried your Peruna.
"I got a bottle of your Peruna and after a week's use of it I began to feel better. I could not eat, sleep, or work, but I have at last found that the medicine that will cure me is Peruna."
For special directions everyone should read "THE ILLS OF LIFE," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.

div.head: A MOTHER AND HER CHILDREN.
div.p: 11, Kitchener Terrace, Tynemouth Road, North Shields, England.
For the sake of other mothers, I must tell you how your Doan's Backache Kidney Bills have helped me.

I have never been strong, and can trace, my kidney trouble back to the days of my childhood. Even when a girl in my teens, I was tired and drowsy all the day, and didn't get restful sleep at nights. As I grew in years, I seemed to get worse, being irregular, and having attacks of palpitation and nervousness. Between 16 and 17 years of age I couldn't go up half-a-dozen steps without resting ; if I attempted to, I fell down. About this age, too, I began to be troubled with sharp pains in the small of the back, and was sometimes taken with dizzy spells.
Time after time I had medicine from the doctor, but it didn't seem to help me at all.

After my 21st birthday, I became more regular, and my health improved, although I still suffered now and then from backache, headaches, and dizziness, and the secretions were irregular in passing I married when I was 24 years of age, and have had, in all, six children, the five born before 1 began with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills being premature. The first lived only 11 months, the second and third are still living ; the fourth lived only 24 hours, and the fifth died within three weeks.

It was about 12 months ago that 1 began taking Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, having heard them spoken highly of. The first box relieved me a good deal, and I bought some more, which considerably eased my back and improved my apatite. By keeping on with the medicine, I grew better in every way. Shortly after this, I gave birth to my sixth child ; it is the only child not prematurely born, and is going on splendidly—better, in fact, than the other two who surd red. If is just two months old now.

Altogether I have used six boxes of Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and they have done me more good than all the doctors' medicine. I sleep better at lights, my appetite is improved, and I am a healthier woman now than I have been for many years.
You are welcome to publish these facts, and I shall be glad if my experience proves helpful to other mothers.
(Signed) (Mrs.) H. MILLER.

Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 13 per box or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,— Max Fischer, Hotel do Nil Street, Mousky, Cairo.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

Réalisable : débiteurs ep 1906 873,492 francs, en 1905 2,967,028 francs, en 1904 310,931 francs.
Disponible : caisse, banquiers et portefeuille : en 1906 1,266,214 francs, en 1905 949,735 francs, en 1904 199,202 fr.
Mémoire : actions d'apports 250,000 fr. chaque année.
PASSIF

Envers la Société (réserves):en 19 .6 120,51 ] fr., en 1905 107,221 fr. et en 1906 37,970 francs.

L'assemblée a réélu S.E. J. de Martino pacha, administrateur, et M. J. B. Fiérez, commissaire.

Avec les chaleurs, les ventes de bière de la Brasserie des Pyramide* ont repris une non velle activité. Pendant les 20 premiers jours île mai, le montant des ventes comparé celui de l'an demies, présente une augmentation de 914 L.E., soit plus de 60 %.
La Brasserie des Pyramides est certainement devenue une de nos meilleures sociétés industrielles.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE PATHE.
div.p: Le succès va grandissant On se dispute loges, fauteuils, places numérotées, etc, et c'eut par centaine que l'on doit refuser les places. Le public est unanime à déclarer la salle ravissante à tous les points de vue et s'ertasie devant la richesse et le bon goût des décorations comme devant la commodité et le confortable des sièges. Inutile de parler du programme impeccable comme toujours.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE.

La Municipalité met en adjudication les ravaux de Dallage de la rue Jebel Zeitoun au quartier Gabbary.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.Eg 525.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Pechnique où il peut être consulté par les inérossés tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les ofires devront être adressées sous pli acheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur do la lunicipalité avant le 4 Juin 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en éance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h.p.m
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mon ion Soumission pour travaux Dallage rue ebel Zeitoun.

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, evra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des ffroaetau plus tard le 4 Juin 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions deasns sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 21 Mai 1907.
L'Administrateur,
30345-3-1 (Sig.) W. P. CHATAWAY.

L'Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Cy Ltd a l'honneur d'informer le Public, que par suite de l'établissement d'un service spécial entre Alexandrie et Ibrahimieh, les changements suivants seront apportés, à partir du 25 Mai courant, dans la marche des trains sur ses réseaux :

lo.— Les trains de l'ancienne ligne Alexandrie Bulkeley Bacos San Stefano, ne s'arrêteront plus aux Haltes de Camp de César et Sporting Club, cette dernière devant être desservie par les trains du Palais.
2o.—Les trains du Palais no s'arrêteront plus à la Halte Camp do César ni à la Station Ibrahimieh, mais desserviront la Halte Sporting Club.
Les voyageurs de l'ancienne ligne de ou pour la Halte Sporting Club devront changer de train à Sidi-Gaber ou a Bulkeley, suivant leur convenance.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire.
div.p: Acis aux Actionnaires.
Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoques en Assemblée générale extraordinaire, le Mereredi 5 Juin 1907, à 3 heures 1/2 de relevée, au Siège Social, au Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR :
Proposition de création et d'émission d'actions de jouissance en augmentation de celles existantes, et par suite, modification de l'art. 12 des statuts.

Pour assister à l'Assemblée, il faut être propriétaire de dix actions au moins et faire le dépôt de ces actions cinq jours avant la réunion au Siège de la Soeieté ou dans l'un des établissements ci après ou leurs succursales: te Crédit Lyonnais, le Credit Foncier Egyptien, la Bampie Impériale Ottomane, l'Anglo Egyptian Bank, la Banque Nationale l'Egypte et la Bank of Egypt.

L'assemblée génerale ne pouvant délibérer valablement que si la proportion d'actions prévue par les statuts est représentée, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont en conséquence priés de faire le dépot de toutes leurs actions.
Le Caire, 1e 10 Mai 1907.
Le Directeur
30255-4-3 ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER COMPANY LTD.
div.p: Avis est donné par la présente qu'une Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire de la Compagnie aura lieu au Bureau de la Compagnie à Alexandrie le 11 Juin 1907 à 4 heures et demie de l'après-midi, pour approuver les résolutions suivantes :
1. L'augmentation du capital de la Compagnie par la création de 20,000 nouvelles actions de £5 nominalo chacune, exclusivement offertes aux actionnaires.
2. De donner pouvoirs au Conseil d'Administration d'emettre ces actions, en totalité ou en partie, au moment et au prix qu'il jugera opportun dans l'interét de la Compagnie.
Cette Assemblée aura lieu a la suite de l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire.

Pour assister ou se faire représenter à cette Assemblée, MM. les propriétaires d'actions au porteur sont informés que, conformément aux Statuts, leurs titres doivent être déposés a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., à Alexandrie, au moins trois jours francs, avant l'Assemblée, ou chez Messr. Barclay & Company Ltd. 1, Pali Mail East, London, S.W., a Londres, 14 jours francs, avant l'Assemblée.
Par ordre du Conseil d'Administration,
H. R. C. BLAGDEN.
30288-4-4 Directeur.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité d Alexandrie a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'elle met au concours trois placés de médécins et un poste de chimiste-pharmacien dans la classe de LE. 16-20 par mois.
Les candidats à ces postes devront accompagner leur demande :-
1° d un diplôme d'une faculté reconnue.
2° d'un certificat de naissance ou tout autre document en tenant lieu.
3° d un certificat de bonne vie et mœurs ét de tous autres documents qu'ils pourront avoir.
Les demandes devront être adressées a l'Administrateteur de la Municipalité jusqu'au 15 juin 1907 au plus tard.
L'Administrateur
W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 21 Mai 1907. 30321-3-3

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité d'Alexandrie a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'elle dispose de six postes provisoires de médecin pour la durée de l'exercise eu cours (1907) pour le service de secours d'urgence de nuit.
Chaque métlecin touchera une rétribution fixé de L.E. 12 par mois.
Les candidats a ces postes devront accompagner leur demande :
1° d'un diplôme d'une faculté reconnue.
2° d'un certificat de naissance ou tout autre document en tenant lieu.
3° d'un certificat de bonne vie et mœurs et de tous autres documents qu'ils pourront avoir.
Les demandes devront être adressées à l'Administrateur de la Municipalité jusqu'an ler Juin au plus tard.
L'Administrateur,
W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 21 Mai 1907. 30330-3-3

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public, que les offres faites le 10 Mai courant, pour l'achat de 561 vieilles portes et fenêtres n'ayant pas été satisfaisantes, l'Administration a décilé de les remettre eu adjudication ainsi que quinze à vingt tonnes environ de vieux bois. En conséquence, il sera procédé le Mercredi vingt neuf Mai courant, à neuf heures du matin, à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, aux Magasins de Gabbary à Alexandrie, du matériel cidessus spécifié provenant des anciens logements du personnel dernièrement démolis à Gabal Zeitoun. Les portes et fenêtres se trouvent à Gabal-Zeitoun. près de la station de Gabbary, où on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m. lies dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

On peut prendre connaissance des conditions de vente et de la liste de ce matériel au bureau Central des Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire) et an bureau de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary à Alexandrie, tous les jours de neuf heures du matin à midi. Les dimanches et jours fériés exceptas.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire «levra, au préalable, verser une somme de LE. 10 (Livres Egyptiennes dix) a titre de dévalt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire dédaré adjudicataire devra jairfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et enlèvera à ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un délai de vingt-cinq jours à compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur jiapier timbré de trente millièmes, si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu du versement du dépôt provisoire, seront adressés par la Poste sous pli recommandé à :—
Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat à Gabbary (Alexandrie)
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Offre our achat de vieux Lus, j'dortes et fenêtres."
Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Adininistration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élèvé ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le driot de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 20 Mai 1907. 30319-2-2

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer et des Télégraphes dé l'Etat a l'honneur d'infonner le Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 20 Avril prochain a midi des offres pour l'extraction et 1er fournitnre de 50,000 mètres cubes de ballast provenant de la carrière de Khatatbeh; et ce conformement aux clauses et conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peut prendre connaissance au Service Central de la Voie et des Travaux au Caire.
Pour être admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire devra verser au préalable à titre de dépôt provisoire LE 60 et joindre le reçu a son offre.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 80 millièmes et rédigées conformément au modèle de soumission annexé au cahier des charges dont on peut obtenir copie au Bureau Central du Service de la Voie contre paiement de P.T. 5.
Elles seront adressées par la Poste sous pli recommandé à :—
Monsieur le Directeur Général, des Chemins de fer de l'Etat et des Télégraphes
Le Caire
et sous double envelope. l'intérieur portant l'inscription suivante :—
Offre pur l'extraction et la fourniture de ballast de Khattatbah."
L'Administration n'est pas tenue d'accepter l'offre la plus basse ni de donner suite aux soumissions présentées,
Le Caire, le 22 Mars, 1907. 30337-2-1

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette"
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published a midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's maiL The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuatious, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the " Egyptian Gazette."
